hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 & 4 \\ 5 & 2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 5\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (0\cdot2)+(4\cdot5) 
\\(5\cdot2)+(2\cdot5)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}20 \\ 20\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}20 \\ 20\end{array}\right]$ is shown below. 

![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9cfd8aa7c9447b4f8b066a7e41d20560d2ab447a)

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}0 & 4 \\ 5 & 2\end{array}\right]$

**Plot the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}2 \\ 5\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}-1 & 4 \\ 5 & 2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 2\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (-1\cdot1)+(4\cdot2) 
\\(5\cdot1)+(2\cdot2)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}7 \\ 9\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}7 \\ 9\end{array}\right]$ is shown below. 

![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/770313d2fc1c04cd85745502d09bcc11a93d953b)

question.content:

$\text E =  \left[\begin{array}{rr}-1 & 4 \\ 5 & 2\end{array}\right]$

**Plot the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}= \left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ 2\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}5 & -2 \\ -1 & 5\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 1\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (5\cdot2)+(-2\cdot1) 
\\(-1\cdot2)+(5\cdot1)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}8 \\ 3\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}8 \\ 3\end{array}\right]$ is shown below. 

![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8ebaab39a38cb64deabb7f8f40837f0c83e6f389)

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}5 & -2 \\ -1 & 5\end{array}\right]$

**Plot the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}2 \\ 1\end{array}\right]$.**

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}2 & 0 \\ -2 & 0\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 1\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (2\cdot-1)+(0\cdot1) 
\\(-2\cdot-1)+(0\cdot1)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}-2 \\ 2\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}-2 \\ 2\end{array}\right]$ is shown below. 

![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9da71ce369d633ae7bcb944ab39ca7714e87f8e0)

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}-2 & -2 \\ -1 & 1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 1\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (-2\cdot2)+(-2\cdot1) 
\\(-1\cdot2)+(1\cdot1)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}-6 \\ -1\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&=  \left[\begin{array}{rr}-1 & -2 \\ -2 & -1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 0\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (-1\cdot2)+(-2\cdot0) 
\\(-2\cdot2)+(-1\cdot0)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}-2 \\ -4\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}-2 \\ -4\end{array}\right]$ is shown below.

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}-1 & 0 \\ 4 & 2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 1\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (-1\cdot0)+(0\cdot1) 
\\(4\cdot0)+(2\cdot1)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}0 \\ 2\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}0 \\ 2\end{array}\right]$ is shown below. 

![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ae15327234d57665c8bb3129d99ef63dc5b0f30f)

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}4 & 2 \\ 0 & -2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 5 \\ 0\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (4\cdot5)+(2\cdot0) 
\\(0\cdot5)+(-2\cdot0)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}20 \\ 0\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&=  \left[\begin{array}{rr}0 & 5 \\ -5 & 5\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 5 \\ 2\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (0\cdot5)+(5\cdot2) 
\\(-5\cdot5)+(5\cdot2)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}10 \\ -15\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}10 \\ -15\end{array}\right]$ is shown below.

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}1 & -1 \\ 1 & 2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ 4\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r} (1\cdot3)+(-1\cdot4) 
\\(1\cdot3)+(2\cdot4)  \end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}-1 \\ 11\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

The plot of $\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}-1 \\ 11\end{array}\right]$ is shown below. 

![graph](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3ae15c41f96a65e5d1a3b929f049cea39d59b806)

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}1 & -1 \\ 1 & 2\end{array}\right]$

**Plot the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}3 \\ 4\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{0} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{-3}\\ 
\blueD{-1} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{-3} & \greenD{0}\\
\blueD{2} & \maroonD{-2} & \goldD{0} & \greenD{1}\\
\blueD{1} & \maroonD{1} & \goldD{-1} & \greenD{-1}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{-5} \\ \maroonD{1} \\ \goldD{3} \\ \greenD{-2}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{0 \cdot-5}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot 1)} + (\goldD{1 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{-3 \cdot -2})\\ 
&(\blueD{-1 \cdot -5}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot 1}) + (\goldD{-3 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot-2})\\
&(\blueD{2 \cdot -5}) + (\maroonD{-2 \cdot1}) + (\goldD{0 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{1 \cdot -2})\\
&(\blueD{1 \cdot -5}) + (\maroonD{1 \cdot 1}) + (\goldD{-1 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{-1 \cdot -2})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}11 \\ -2 \\ -14\\ -5\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}11 \\ -2 \\ -14\\ -5\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}0 & 2 & 1 & -3\\ 
-1 & 2 & -3 & 0\\
2 & -2 & 0 &1\\
1 & 1 & -1 & -1\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}-5 \\ 1 \\ 3 \\-2\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{2} & \maroonD{7} & \goldD{9} & \greenD{10}\\ 
\blueD{1} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{-3} & \greenD{4}\\
\blueD{0} & \maroonD{-2} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{2}\\
\blueD{9} & \maroonD{0} & \goldD{0} & \greenD{0}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{1} \\ \maroonD{2} \\ \goldD{-1} \\ \greenD{4}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{2 \cdot1}) + (\maroonD{7 \cdot 2)} + (\goldD{9 \cdot -1}) + (\greenD{10 \cdot 4})\\ 
&(\blueD{1 \cdot 1}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot 2}) + (\goldD{-3 \cdot -1}) + (\greenD{4 \cdot4})\\
&(\blueD{0 \cdot 1}) + (\maroonD{-2 \cdot2}) + (\goldD{1 \cdot -1}) + (\greenD{2 \cdot 4})\\
&(\blueD{9 \cdot 1}) + (\maroonD{0 \cdot 2}) + (\goldD{0 \cdot -1}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot 4})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}47 \\ 24 \\ 3\\ 9\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}47 \\ 24 \\ 3\\ 9\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}2 & 7 & 9 & 10\\ 
1 & 2 & -3 & 4\\
0 & -2 & 1 & 2\\
9 & 0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 2 \\ -1 \\4\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{1} & \maroonD{1} & \goldD{2} & \greenD{1}\\ 
\blueD{4} & \maroonD{7} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{0}\\
\blueD{3} & \maroonD{3} & \goldD{6} & \greenD{8}\\
\blueD{0} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{2} & \greenD{4}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{6} \\ \maroonD{2} \\ \goldD{1} \\ \greenD{0}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{1 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{1 \cdot 2)} + (\goldD{2 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{1 \cdot 0})\\ 
&(\blueD{4 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{7 \cdot 2}) + (\goldD{1 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot 0})\\
&(\blueD{3 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{3 \cdot2}) + (\goldD{6 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{8 \cdot 0})\\
&(\blueD{0 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot 2}) + (\goldD{2 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{4 \cdot 0 })\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}10 \\ 39 \\ 30\\ 6\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}10 \\ 39 \\ 30\\ 6\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}1 & 1 & 2 & 1\\ 
4 & 7 & 1 & 0\\
3 & 3 & 6 &8\\
0 & 2 & 2 & 4\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}6 \\ 2 \\ 1 \\0\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{1} & \maroonD{-2} & \goldD{-3} & \greenD{0}\\ 
\blueD{0} & \maroonD{1} & \goldD{-2} & \greenD{1}\\
\blueD{-4} & \maroonD{-4} & \goldD{7} & \greenD{6}\\
\blueD{0} & \maroonD{1} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{0}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{9} \\ \maroonD{-2} \\ \goldD{-8} \\ \greenD{5}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{1 \cdot9}) + (\maroonD{-2 \cdot -2)} + (\goldD{-3 \cdot -8}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot 5})\\ 
&(\blueD{0 \cdot 9}) + (\maroonD{1 \cdot -2}) + (\goldD{-2 \cdot -8}) + (\greenD{1 \cdot5})\\
&(\blueD{-4 \cdot 9}) + (\maroonD{-4 \cdot-2}) + (\goldD{7 \cdot -8}) + (\greenD{6 \cdot 5})\\
&(\blueD{0 \cdot 9}) + (\maroonD{1 \cdot -2}) + (\goldD{1 \cdot -8}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot 5})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}37 \\ 19 \\ -54\\ -10\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}37 \\ 19 \\ -54\\ -10\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}1 & -2 & -3& 0\\ 
0 & 1 & -2 & 1\\
-4 & -4 & 7 &6\\
0 & 1 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}9 \\ -2 \\ -8 \\5\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{4} & \maroonD{4} & \goldD{7} & \greenD{0}\\ 
\blueD{9} & \maroonD{9} & \goldD{2} & \greenD{5}\\
\blueD{5} & \maroonD{6} & \goldD{7} & \greenD{0}\\
\blueD{-1} & \maroonD{7} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{4}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{-6} \\ \maroonD{1} \\ \goldD{3} \\ \greenD{-2}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{4 \cdot-6}) + (\maroonD{4 \cdot 1)} + (\goldD{7 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot -2})\\ 
&(\blueD{9 \cdot -6}) + (\maroonD{9 \cdot 1}) + (\goldD{2 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{5 \cdot-2})\\
&(\blueD{5 \cdot -6}) + (\maroonD{6 \cdot1}) + (\goldD{7 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot -2})\\
&(\blueD{-1 \cdot -6}) + (\maroonD{7 \cdot 1}) + (\goldD{1 \cdot 3}) + (\greenD{4 \cdot -2})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -49 \\ -3\\ 8\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -49 \\ -3\\ 8\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}4 & 4 & 7 & 0\\ 
9 & 9 & 2 & 5\\
5 & 6 & 7 &0\\
-1 & 7 & 1 & 4\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}-6 \\ 1 \\ 3 \\-2\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{2} & \maroonD{-10} & \goldD{-6} & \greenD{8}\\ 
\blueD{-3} & \maroonD{0} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{5}\\
\blueD{-4} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{8} & \greenD{0}\\
\blueD{2} & \maroonD{-9} & \goldD{6} & \greenD{5}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{7} \\ \maroonD{7} \\ \goldD{1} \\ \greenD{0}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{2 \cdot7}) + (\maroonD{-10 \cdot 7)} + (\goldD{-6 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{8 \cdot 0})\\ 
&(\blueD{-3 \cdot 7}) + (\maroonD{0 \cdot 7}) + (\goldD{1 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{5 \cdot0})\\
&(\blueD{-4 \cdot 7}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot7}) + (\goldD{8 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot 0})\\
&(\blueD{2 \cdot 7}) + (\maroonD{-9 \cdot 7}) + (\goldD{6 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{5 \cdot 0})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}-62 \\ -20 \\ -6\\ -43\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}-62 \\ -20 \\ -6\\ -43\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}2 & -10 & -6 & 8\\ 
-3 & 0 & 1 & 5\\
-4 & 2 & 8 &0\\
2 & -9 & 6 & 5\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}7 \\ 7 \\ 1 \\0\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{6} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{8} & \greenD{3}\\ 
\blueD{1} & \maroonD{1} & \goldD{2} & \greenD{5}\\
\blueD{3} & \maroonD{3} & \goldD{7} & \greenD{0}\\
\blueD{4} & \maroonD{6} & \goldD{8} & \greenD{1}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{9} \\ \maroonD{-7} \\ \goldD{5} \\ \greenD{-7}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{6 \cdot9}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot -7)} + (\goldD{8 \cdot 5}) + (\greenD{3 \cdot -7})\\ 
&(\blueD{1 \cdot 9}) + (\maroonD{1 \cdot -7}) + (\goldD{2 \cdot 5}) + (\greenD{5 \cdot-7})\\
&(\blueD{3 \cdot 9}) + (\maroonD{3 \cdot-7}) + (\goldD{7 \cdot 5}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot -7})\\
&(\blueD{4 \cdot 9}) + (\maroonD{6 \cdot -7}) + (\goldD{8 \cdot 5}) + (\greenD{1 \cdot -7})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}59 \\ -23 \\ 41\\ 27\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}59 \\ -23 \\ 41\\ 27\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}6 & 2 & 8 & 3\\ 
1 & 1 & 2 & 5\\
3 & 3 & 7 &0\\
4 & 6 & 8 & 1\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}9 \\ -7 \\ 5 \\-7\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{-5} & \maroonD{5} & \goldD{4} & \greenD{6}\\ 
\blueD{3} & \maroonD{8} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{2}\\
\blueD{0} & \maroonD{4} & \goldD{0} & \greenD{-5}\\
\blueD{6} & \maroonD{-13} & \goldD{8} & \greenD{1}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{6} \\ \maroonD{0} \\ \goldD{10} \\ \greenD{5}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{-5 \cdot6}) + (\maroonD{5 \cdot 0)} + (\goldD{4 \cdot 10}) + (\greenD{6 \cdot 5})\\ 
&(\blueD{3 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{8 \cdot 0}) + (\goldD{1 \cdot 10}) + (\greenD{2 \cdot5})\\
&(\blueD{0 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{4 \cdot0}) + (\goldD{0 \cdot 10}) + (\greenD{-5 \cdot 5})\\
&(\blueD{6 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{-13 \cdot 0}) + (\goldD{8 \cdot 10}) + (\greenD{1 \cdot 5})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}40 \\ 38 \\ -25\\  121\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}40 \\ 38 \\ -25\\  121\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}-5 & 5 & 4 & 6\\ 
3 & 8 & 1 & 2\\
0 & 4 & 0 &-5\\
6 & -13 & 8 & 1\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}6 \\ 0 \\ 10 \\5\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{5} & \maroonD{4} & \goldD{7} & \greenD{0}\\ 
\blueD{3} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{6} & \greenD{1}\\
\blueD{1} & \maroonD{1} & \goldD{2} & \greenD{5}\\
\blueD{8} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{-6} & \greenD{-9}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{6} \\ \maroonD{-3} \\ \goldD{1} \\ \greenD{4}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{5 \cdot6}) + (\maroonD{4 \cdot -3)} + (\goldD{7 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{0 \cdot 4})\\ 
&(\blueD{3 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot -3}) + (\goldD{6 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{1 \cdot4})\\
&(\blueD{1 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{1 \cdot-3}) + (\goldD{2 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{5 \cdot 4})\\
&(\blueD{8 \cdot 6}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot -3}) + (\goldD{-6 \cdot 1}) + (\greenD{-9 \cdot 4})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}25 \\ 22 \\ 25\\ 0\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}25 \\ 22 \\ 25\\ 0\end{array}\right]$

question.content:
The transformation $\text E\,\vec{x}$ is defined by the following matrix.

$\text E = \left[\begin{array}{rr}5 & 4 & 7 & 0\\ 
3 & 2 & 6 & 1\\
1 & 1 & 2 &5\\
8 & 2 & -6 & -9\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}6 \\ -3 \\ 1 \\4\end{array}\right]$.** 

[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###Background 

A transformation matrix, $\text T$, is a matrix that takes a given vector, $p$, and transforms it into another vector. The transformation matrix must have the same number of columns as the vector has rows. Then the product $\text T\vec{p}$ yields a new vector.

###Transforming $\vec{v}$ 

To transform $\vec{v}$ by $\text E$, we must take the product $\text E\vec{v}$. 

$\begin{align}\text E\vec{v}&= \left[\begin{array}{rr}\blueD{2} & \maroonD{2} & \goldD{3} & \greenD{-5}\\ 
\blueD{1} & \maroonD{0} & \goldD{1} & \greenD{5}\\
\blueD{5} & \maroonD{-6} & \goldD{-4} & \greenD{2}\\
\blueD{3} & \maroonD{3} & \goldD{4} & \greenD{-6}\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r}\blueD{-4} \\ \maroonD{-4} \\ \goldD{8} \\ \greenD{0}\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}&(\blueD{2 \cdot-4}) + (\maroonD{2 \cdot -4)} + (\goldD{3 \cdot 8}) + (\greenD{-5 \cdot 0})\\ 
&(\blueD{1 \cdot -4}) + (\maroonD{0 \cdot -4}) + (\goldD{1 \cdot 8}) + (\greenD{5 \cdot0})\\
&(\blueD{5 \cdot -4}) + (\maroonD{-6 \cdot-4}) + (\goldD{-4 \cdot 8}) + (\greenD{2 \cdot 0})\\
&(\blueD{3 \cdot -4}) + (\maroonD{3 \cdot -4}) + (\goldD{4 \cdot 8}) + (\greenD{-6 \cdot 0})\end{array}\right]
\\\\
&=\left[\begin{array}{r}8 \\ 4 \\ -28\\ 8\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$\text E\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}8 \\ 4 \\ -28\\ 8\end{array}\right]$

**Find the result of $\text E\,\vec{v}$ for $\vec{v}=\left[\begin{array}{r}-4 \\ -4 \\ 8 \\0\end{array}\right]$.**
